question.content:
A sector with a central angle measure of $\purpleD{175\degree}$ has a radius of $\maroonD{12\,\text{cm}}$.



[[☃ image 1]]

 **What is the area of the sector?**  

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A circle with a radius of twelve centimeters. A sector is highlighted. The central angle is equals one hundred seventy-five degrees.

hints.content:
###Finding the area of the whole circle

$\begin{align}
\blueE{\text{Area}_{\text{circle}}} &= \pi \maroonD{r}^2\\\\
&=\pi (\maroonD{12})^2\\\\
&=\blueE{144\pi}
\end{align}$

The area of the whole circle is $\blueE{144\pi\,\text{cm}^2}$.

###Solving for the area of the sector

Let's use $\goldE{A_\text{s}}$ to represent the area of the sector.

$\begin{align}
\dfrac{ \purpleD{175}}{360}&=\dfrac{\goldE{A_{\text{s}}}}{\blueE{144\pi}}\\\\
\blueE{144\pi} \cdot\dfrac{ \purpleD{175}}{360}&=\dfrac{\goldE{A_{\text{s}}}}{\cancel{\blueE{144\pi}}}\cdot \cancel{\blueE{144\pi}}\\\\
\goldE{70\pi}&=\goldE{A_{\text{s}}}
\end{align}$

###Solution

The area of the sector is $70\pi\,\text{cm}^2$.

question.content:
A sector with a central angle measure of $\purpleD{200\degree}$ has a radius of $\maroonD{9\,\text{cm}}$.



[[☃ image 1]]

 **What is the area of the sector?**  

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A circle with a radius of nine centimeters. A sector is highlighted. The central angle is equals two hundred degrees.

hints.content:
###Finding the area of the whole circle

$\begin{align}
\blueE{\text{Area}_{\text{circle}}} &= \pi \maroonD{r}^2\\\\
&=\pi (\maroonD{9})^2\\\\
&=\blueE{81\pi}
\end{align}$

The area of the whole circle is $\blueE{81\pi\,\text{cm}^2}$.

###Solving for the area of the sector

Let's use $\goldE{A_\text{s}}$ to represent the area of the sector.

$\begin{align}
\dfrac{ \purpleD{200}}{360}&=\dfrac{\goldE{A_{\text{s}}}}{\blueE{81\pi}}\\\\
\blueE{81\pi} \cdot\dfrac{ \purpleD{200}}{360}&=\dfrac{\goldE{A_{\text{s}}}}{\cancel{\blueE{81\pi}}}\cdot \cancel{\blueE{81\pi}}\\\\
\goldE{45\pi}&=\goldE{A_{\text{s}}}
\end{align}$

###Solution

The area of the sector is $45\pi\,\text{cm}^2$.

&=\pi (\maroonD{8})^2\\\\

\end{align}$

The area of the whole circle is $\blueE{64\pi\,\text{cm}^2}$.

###Solving for the area of the sector

$\begin{align}

###Solution

question.content:
A sector with a radius of $\maroonD{10\,\text{cm}}$ has a central angle measure of $\purpleD{252\degree}$.



[[☃ image 1]]

 **What is the area of the sector?**  

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A circle with a radius of ten centimeters. A sector is highlighted. The central angle is equals two hundred fifty-two degrees.

hints.content:
###Finding the area of the whole circle

$\begin{align}
\blueE{\text{Area}_{\text{circle}}} &= \pi \maroonD{r}^2\\\\
&=\pi (\maroonD{10})^2\\\\
&=\blueE{100\pi}
\end{align}$

The area of the whole circle is $\blueE{100\pi\,\text{cm}^2}$.

###Solving for the area of the sector

Let's use $\goldE{A_\text{s}}$ to represent the area of the sector.

$\begin{align}
\dfrac{ \purpleD{252}}{360}&=\dfrac{\goldE{A_{\text{s}}}}{\blueE{100\pi}}\\\\
\blueE{100\pi} \cdot\dfrac{ \purpleD{252}}{360}&=\dfrac{\goldE{A_{\text{s}}}}{\cancel{\blueE{100\pi}}}\cdot \cancel{\blueE{100\pi}}\\\\
\goldE{70\pi}&=\goldE{A_{\text{s}}}
\end{align}$

###Solution

The area of the sector is $70\pi\,\text{cm}^2$.

question.content:
A sector with a radius $\maroonD{7\,\text{cm}}$ has an area of $\goldE{\dfrac{49}{3}\pi\,\text{cm}^2}$.



[[☃ image 1]]

 **What is the central angle measure of the sector in degrees?**  

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A circle with a radius of seven centimeters. A sector is highlighted. The area of the sector is forty-nine pi divided by three centimeters squared.

hints.content:
###Finding the area of the whole circle

$\begin{align}
\blueE{\text{Area}_{\text{circle}}} &= \pi \maroonD{r}^2\\\\
&=\pi (\maroonD{7})^2\\\\
&=\blueE{49\pi}
\end{align}$

The area of the whole circle is $\blueE{49\pi\,\text{cm}^2}$.

###Solving for the central angle measure of the sector

We can substitute in the values for the area of the sector and area of the whole circle.

$\begin{align}
\dfrac{ \purpleD{\theta}}{360}&=\dfrac{\goldE{\left( \dfrac{49}{3}\pi\right)}}{\blueE{49\pi}}\\\\
\cancel{360}\cdot\dfrac{\purpleD{\theta}}{\cancel{360}}&=\dfrac{\goldE{\left(\dfrac{49}{3}\pi\right)}}{\blueE{49\pi}}\cdot 360\\\\
\purpleD{\theta}&=120
\end{align}$

###Solution

The central angle measure of the sector is $120\degree$.

question.content:
A sector with a radius $\maroonD{18\,\text{cm}}$ has an area of $\goldE{234\pi\,\text{cm}^2}$.



[[☃ image 1]]

 **What is the central angle measure of the sector in degrees?**  

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A circle with a radius of eighteen centimeters. A sector is highlighted. The area of the sector is two hundred thirty-four pi centimeters squared.

hints.content:
###Finding the area of the whole circle

$\begin{align}
\blueE{\text{Area}_{\text{circle}}} &= \pi \maroonD{r}^2\\\\
&=\pi (\maroonD{18})^2\\\\
&=\blueE{324\pi}
\end{align}$

The area of the whole circle is $\blueE{324\pi\,\text{cm}^2}$.

###Solving for the central angle measure of the sector

We can substitute in the values for the area of the sector and area of the whole circle.

$\begin{align}
\dfrac{ \purpleD{\theta}}{360}&=\dfrac{\goldE{234\pi}}{\blueE{324\pi}}\\\\
\cancel{360}\cdot\dfrac{\purpleD{\theta}}{\cancel{360}}&=\dfrac{\goldE{234\pi}}{\blueE{324\pi}}\cdot 360\\\\
\purpleD{\theta}&=260
\end{align}$

###Solution

The central angle measure of the sector is $260\degree$.

question.content:

$\begin{align}
\blueE{\text{Area}_{\text{circle}}} &= \pi \maroonD{r}^2\\\\
&=\pi (\maroonD{3})^2\\\\

\end{align}$

The area of the whole circle is $\blueE{9\pi\,\text{cm}^2}$.

###Solving for the central angle measure of the sector

We can substitute in the values for the area of the sector and area of the whole circle.

$\begin{align}
\dfrac{ \purpleD{\theta}}{360}&=\dfrac{\goldE{\left( \dfrac{11}{2}\pi\right)}}{\blueE{9\pi}}\\\\
\cancel{360}\cdot\dfrac{\purpleD{\theta}}{\cancel{360}}&=\dfrac{\goldE{\left(\dfrac{11}{2}\pi\right)}}{\blueE{9\pi}}\cdot 360\\\\
\purpleD{\theta}&=220
\end{align}$

###Solution

The central angle measure of the sector is $220\degree$.

A sector with an area of $\goldE{30\pi\,\text{cm}^2}$ has a radius of $\maroonD{10\,\text{cm}}$.

question.content:
A sector with an area of $\goldE{140\pi\,\text{cm}^2}$ has a radius of $\maroonD{20\,\text{cm}}$.



[[☃ image 1]]

 **What is the central angle measure of the sector in degrees?**  

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A circle with a radius of twenty centimeters. A sector is highlighted. The area of the sector is one hundred forty pi centimeters squared.

hints.content:
###Finding the area of the whole circle

$\begin{align}
\blueE{\text{Area}_{\text{circle}}} &= \pi \maroonD{r}^2\\\\
&=\pi (\maroonD{20})^2\\\\
&=\blueE{400\pi}
\end{align}$

The area of the whole circle is $\blueE{400\pi\,\text{cm}^2}$.

###Solving for the central angle measure of the sector

We can substitute in the values for the area of the sector and area of the whole circle.

$\begin{align}
\dfrac{ \purpleD{\theta}}{360}&=\dfrac{\goldE{140\pi}}{\blueE{400\pi}}\\\\
\cancel{360}\cdot\dfrac{\purpleD{\theta}}{\cancel{360}}&=\dfrac{\goldE{140\pi}}{\blueE{400\pi}}\cdot 360\\\\
\purpleD{\theta}&=126
\end{align}$

###Solution

The central angle measure of the sector is $126\degree$.

question.content:
A sector with a radius of $\maroonD{15\,\text{cm}}$ has a central angle measure of $\purpleD{\dfrac{8\pi}{5}}$ (in radians).



[[☃ image 1]]

 **What is the area of the sector?**  

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A circle with a radius of fifteen centimeters. A sector is highlighted. The area of the sector is eight pi over five centimeters squared.

options.showPrompt: What is that angle measure with π?
options.explanation:
The angle measure is in **radians**. One radian is the angle measure that we turn to travel one radius length around the circumference of a circle.



[[☃ image 1]]

So **radians** are the constant of proportionality between an arc length and the radius length.

It takes $2\pi$ radians (a little more than $6$ radians) to make a complete turn about the center of a unit circle.


[[☃ image 2]]

options.alt: A circle. There are two radii that form a central angle. The arc length is shown to be equal to the length of the radius.

A circle broken into seven sectors. Six of the sectors have a central angle measure of one radian and an arc length equal to length of the radius of a circle. The seventh sector is a smaller sector. The seven sectors represent the little more than six radians that it takes to make a complete turn around the center of a circle.

hints.content:
###Finding the area of the whole circle

$\begin{align}
\blueE{\text{Area}_{\text{circle}}} &= \pi \maroonD{r}^2\\\\
&=\pi (\maroonD{15})^2\\\\
&=\blueE{225\pi}
\end{align}$

The area of the whole circle is $\blueE{225\pi\,\text{cm}^2}$.

###Solving for the area of the sector

Let's use $\goldE{A_\text{s}}$ to represent the area of the sector.

$\begin{align}
\dfrac{ \purpleD{\left( \dfrac{8\pi}{5}\right)}}{2\pi}&=\dfrac{\goldE{A_{\text{s}}}}{\blueE{225\pi}}\\\\
\blueE{225\pi} \cdot\dfrac{ \purpleD{\left( \dfrac{8\pi}{5}\right)}}{2\pi}&=\dfrac{\goldE{A_{\text{s}}}}{\cancel{\blueE{225\pi}}}\cdot \cancel{\blueE{225\pi}}\\\\
\goldE{180\pi}&=\goldE{A_{\text{s}}}
\end{align}$

###Solution

The area of the sector is $180\pi\,\text{cm}^2$.

question.content:
A sector with a radius of $\maroonD{6\,\text{cm}}$ has a central angle measure of $\purpleD{\dfrac{4\pi}{9}}$ (in radians).



[[☃ image 1]]

 **What is the area of the sector?**  

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A circle with a radius of six centimeters. A sector is highlighted. The central angle is equals four pi over nine radians.

options.showPrompt: What is that angle measure with π?
options.explanation:
The angle measure is in **radians**. One radian is the angle measure that we turn to travel one radius length around the circumference of a circle.



[[☃ image 1]]

So **radians** are the constant of proportionality between an arc length and the radius length.

It takes $2\pi$ radians (a little more than $6$ radians) to make a complete turn about the center of a unit circle.



[[☃ image 2]]

options.alt: A circle. There are two radii that form a central angle. The arc length is shown to be equal to the length of the radius.

A circle broken into seven sectors. Six of the sectors have a central angle measure of one radian and an arc length equal to length of the radius of a circle. The seventh sector is a smaller sector. The seven sectors represent the little more than six radians that it takes to make a complete turn around the center of a circle.

hints.content:
###Finding the area of the whole circle

$\begin{align}
\blueE{\text{Area}_{\text{circle}}} &= \pi \maroonD{r}^2\\\\
&=\pi (\maroonD{6})^2\\\\
&=\blueE{36\pi}
\end{align}$

The area of the whole circle is $\blueE{36\pi\,\text{cm}^2}$.

###Solving for the area of the sector

Let's use $\goldE{A_\text{s}}$ to represent the area of the sector.

$\begin{align}
\dfrac{ \purpleD{\left( \dfrac{4\pi}{9}\right)}}{2\pi}&=\dfrac{\goldE{A_{\text{s}}}}{\blueE{36\pi}}\\\\
\blueE{36\pi} \cdot\dfrac{ \purpleD{\left( \dfrac{4\pi}{9}\right)}}{2\pi}&=\dfrac{\goldE{A_{\text{s}}}}{\cancel{\blueE{36\pi}}}\cdot \cancel{\blueE{36\pi}}\\\\
\goldE{8\pi}&=\goldE{A_{\text{s}}}
\end{align}$

###Solution

The area of the sector is $8\pi\,\text{cm}^2$.

question.content:
A sector with an area of $\goldE{48\pi\,\text{cm}^2}$ has a radius of $\maroonD{16\,\text{cm}}$.



[[☃ image 1]]

 **What is the central angle measure of the sector in radians?**  

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A circle with a radius of sixteen centimeters. A sector is highlighted. The central angle is equals forty-eight pi radians.

options.showPrompt: What is that angle measure with π?
options.explanation:
The angle measure is in **radians**. One radian is the angle measure that we turn to travel one radius length around the circumference of a circle.



[[☃ image 1]]

So **radians** are the constant of proportionality between an arc length and the radius length.

It takes $2\pi$ radians (a little more than $6$ radians) to make a complete turn about the center of a unit circle.



[[☃ image 2]]

options.alt: A circle. There are two radii that form a central angle. The arc length is shown to be equal to the length of the radius.

A circle broken into seven sectors. Six of the sectors have a central angle measure of one radian and an arc length equal to length of the radius of a circle. The seventh sector is a smaller sector. The seven sectors represent the little more than six radians that it takes to make a complete turn around the center of a circle.

hints.content:
###Finding the area of the whole circle

$\begin{align}
\blueE{\text{Area}_{\text{circle}}} &= \pi \maroonD{r}^2\\\\
&=\pi (\maroonD{16})^2\\\\
&=\blueE{256\pi}
\end{align}$

The area of the whole circle is $\blueE{256\pi\,\text{cm}^2}$.

###Solving for the central angle measure of the sector

We can substitute in the values for the area of the sector and area of the whole circle.

$\begin{align}
\dfrac{ \purpleD{\theta}}{2\pi}&=\dfrac{\goldE{48\pi}}{\blueE{256\pi}}\\\\
\cancel{2\pi}\cdot\dfrac{\purpleD{\theta}}{\cancel{2\pi}}&=\dfrac{\goldE{48\pi}}{\blueE{256\pi}}\cdot 2\pi\\\\
\purpleD{\theta}&=\dfrac{3\pi}{8}
\end{align}$

###Solution

The central angle measure of the sector is $\dfrac{3\pi}{8}$ (in radians).

We can substitute in the values for the area of the sector and area of the whole circle.

$\begin{align}
\dfrac{ \purpleD{\theta}}{2\pi}&=\dfrac{\goldE{26\pi}}{\blueE{36\pi}}\\\\
\cancel{2\pi}\cdot\dfrac{\purpleD{\theta}}{\cancel{2\pi}}&=\dfrac{\goldE{26\pi}}{\blueE{36\pi}}\cdot 2\pi\\\\
\purpleD{\theta}&=\dfrac{13\pi}{9}
\end{align}$

###Solution

The central angle measure of the sector is $\dfrac{13\pi}{9}$ (in radians).

question.content:
A sector with a radius of $\maroonD{8\,\text{cm}}$ has an area of $\goldE{56\pi\,\text{cm}^2}$.



[[☃ image 1]]

 **What is the central angle measure of the sector in radians?**  

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A circle with a radius of eight centimeters. A sector is highlighted. The area of the sector is fifty-six pi centimeters squared.

options.showPrompt: What is that angle measure with π?
options.explanation:
The angle measure is in **radians**. One radian is the angle measure that we turn to travel one radius length around the circumference of a circle.



[[☃ image 1]]

So **radians** are the constant of proportionality between an arc length and the radius length.

It takes $2\pi$ radians (a little more than $6$ radians) to make a complete turn about the center of a unit circle.



[[☃ image 2]]

options.alt: A circle. There are two radii that form a central angle. The arc length is shown to be equal to the length of the radius.

A circle broken into seven sectors. Six of the sectors have a central angle measure of one radian and an arc length equal to length of the radius of a circle. The seventh sector is a smaller sector. The seven sectors represent the little more than six radians that it takes to make a complete turn around the center of a circle.

hints.content:
###Finding the area of the whole circle

$\begin{align}
\blueE{\text{Area}_{\text{circle}}} &= \pi \maroonD{r}^2\\\\
&=\pi (\maroonD{8})^2\\\\
&=\blueE{64\pi}
\end{align}$

The area of the whole circle is $\blueE{64\pi\,\text{cm}^2}$.

###Solving for the central angle measure of the sector

We can substitute in the values for the area of the sector and area of the whole circle.

$\begin{align}
\dfrac{ \purpleD{\theta}}{2\pi}&=\dfrac{\goldE{56\pi}}{\blueE{64\pi}}\\\\
\cancel{2\pi}\cdot\dfrac{\purpleD{\theta}}{\cancel{2\pi}}&=\dfrac{\goldE{56\pi}}{\blueE{64\pi}}\cdot 2\pi\\\\
\purpleD{\theta}&=\dfrac{7\pi}{4}
\end{align}$

###Solution

The central angle measure of the sector is $\dfrac{7\pi}{4}$ (in radians).

The area of the whole circle is $\blueE{81\pi\,\text{cm}^2}$.

question.content:
A sector with a radius of $\maroonD{12\,\text{cm}}$ has an area of $\goldE{60\pi\,\text{cm}^2}$.

 **What is the central angle measure of the sector in radians?**  

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A circle with a radius of twelve centimeters. A sector is highlighted. The area of the sector is sixty pi centimeters squared.

options.showPrompt: What is that angle measure with π?
options.explanation:
The angle measure is in **radians**. One radian is the angle measure that we turn to travel one radius length around the circumference of a circle.



[[☃ image 1]]

So **radians** are the constant of proportionality between an arc length and the radius length.

It takes $2\pi$ radians (a little more than $6$ radians) to make a complete turn about the center of a unit circle.



[[☃ image 2]]

options.alt: A circle. There are two radii that form a central angle. The arc length is shown to be equal to the length of the radius.

A circle broken into seven sectors. Six of the sectors have a central angle measure of one radian and an arc length equal to length of the radius of a circle. The seventh sector is a smaller sector. The seven sectors represent the little more than six radians that it takes to make a complete turn around the center of a circle.

hints.content:
###Finding the area of the whole circle

$\begin{align}
\blueE{\text{Area}_{\text{circle}}} &= \pi \maroonD{r}^2\\\\
&=\pi (\maroonD{12})^2\\\\
&=\blueE{144\pi}
\end{align}$

The area of the whole circle is $\blueE{144\pi\,\text{cm}^2}$.

###Solving for the central angle measure of the sector

\dfrac{ \purpleD{\theta}}{2\pi}&=\dfrac{\goldE{60\pi}}{\blueE{144\pi}}\\\\
